# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
This is for @angular/service-worker

### Description
As [Angular Service worker doc](https://angular.io/guide/service-worker-config) described:

> You can also emulate a third strategy, staleWhileRevalidate, which returns cached data (if available), but also fetches fresh data from the network in the background for next time.

If we can receive the `fresh data` in our code, we can compare the `fresh data` with the `cache data `that the application is using, and to do sth like: **Show content from cache, update cache in background and show updated content as soon as it arrives**


### Describe the solution you'd like
I would like to do this in my code like:
```
this.serviceWorker.subscribe((data, url)=> {
  if (data != old data) {
    update application
  }
})
```


### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?-->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ability to receive data that service worker fetch from network" (#40277)

Issues.Title: @angular/compiler-cli downleveling decorators possibly causing RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded with isReferencedAliasDeclaration
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/compiler-cli version >=10 ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this issue was not happening was: 9 It started happening in Angular 10 with the introduction of decorator downleveling: ``` compiler-cli: downlevel angular decorators to static properties (#37382) (323651b), closes #30586 #30106 #30586 #30141 ``` PR: https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/37382 ### Description We just did an upgrade from Angular 9->11 and started seeing this problem in our biggest application when we run ng serve. We have a monorepo setup with Nx. After the upgrade we were able to start 3 other applications that are a little bit smaller than previously mentioned one. Since the error is quite unclear i started investigating what could be the cause and found only one issue report similar to this one here: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/18792 But that seemed to be an issue that was caused in their own setup. I also looked if we had anything similar, but with no luck. I also tried doing divide and conquer approach removing some modules from the application and that made it work. However there was no exact rule which modules work and which dont, the distribution was quite random expect one thing if i made the app smaller, then it worked(by removing bigger modules). Next on my list was to add some logging in `patchAliasReferenceResolutionOrDie` for the nodes that were being traversed and I did not see any circular dependency that would cause an infinite recursion. Then i tried adjusting the implementation of `isReferencedAliasDeclaration` and was able to make this work by changing this part here: ```ts // Before emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration = function(node, ...args) { if (isAliasImportDeclaration(node) && referencedAliases.has(node)) { return true; } return originalReferenceResolution.call(emitResolver, node, ...args); }; // After emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration = function(node, checkChildren) { if (isAliasImportDeclaration(node) && referencedAliases.has(node)) { return true; } return originalReferenceResolution.call(emitResolver, node, checkChildren); }; ``` https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.ts#L87 This change was made so that `isReferencedAliasDeclaration` looks exactly like the typescript implementation https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/microsoft/TypeScript@3eaa7c65f6f076a08a5f7f1946fd0df7c7430259/-/blob/src/compiler/checker.ts#L36179-36192 And this fixed the issue. My 2 cents on why this fixed it is better explained when looking at compiled code of the function ```js // Before emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration = function (node) { var args = []; for (var _i = 1, _len = arguments.length; _i < _len; _i++) { args[_i - 1] = arguments[_i]; } if (isAliasImportDeclaration(node) && referencedAliases.has(node)) { return true; } return originalReferenceResolution.call.apply(originalReferenceResolution, tslib_1.__spread([emitResolver, node], args)); }; // After emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration = function (node, checkChildren) { if (isAliasImportDeclaration(node) && referencedAliases.has(node)) { return true; } return originalReferenceResolution.call(emitResolver, node, checkChildren); }; ``` During tree traversal `isReferencedAliasDeclaration` in each call is creating its own local array copying the arguments and then spreading that back again to original implementation, so i suppose after certain number of calls the memory just gets over allowed threshold and breaks. ## üî• Exception or Error 



Error: RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded
    at Set.has ()
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:84:69)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)
    at Object.emitResolver.isReferencedAliasDeclaration (/monorepo/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/transformers/patch_alias_reference_resolution.js:87:53)

Issues.Title: Docs: Add 'Adding reactivity' section to 'Try It' in the 'Getting Started' guide
Issues.Body: # üìö Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description In the **[Try It](https://angular.io/start)** section the shopping app that is being created is small and doesn't fully show the power of Angular's (with RxJS) reactivity system. - What do I mean by that? In the current app, the user can buy things, and they get added to the cart. On click of the buy button, the app shows just an alert that the item was bought and that's all (the item is added in the cart items array in the service in the background). If we want to show the number of the cart items on the **top bar component** we cannot do it by just showing the length of the cart items array. Like this: ```ts export class TopBarComponent { count = this.cart.getItems().length; constructor(private cart: CartService) {} } ``` ```html shopping_cart Checkout {{ count }} ``` It won't work, because when we buy another item the change detection will not be triggered for that component, because Angular isn't listening to that value. And here is where RxJS comes into play. What we can do is to introduce a `BehaviourSubject` in the cart service and explain it and the pros of using RxJS for this kind of use-cases. It can be a simple pattern like this: ```ts export class CartService { private items = new BehaviorSubject([]); items$ = this.items.asObservable().pipe(distinctUntilChanged()); cartCount$ = this.items$.pipe(map(items => items.length)); addToCart(product: Product): void { const currentItems = this.items.value; this.items.next([...currentItems, product]); } clearCart(): void { this.items.next([]); } } ``` and use it like this: ```ts @Component({ ... changeDetection: ChangeDetectionStrategy.OnPush }) export class TopBarComponent { cartCount$ = this.cartService.cartCount$; constructor(private cartService: CartService) {} } ``` ```html shopping_cart Checkout ({{ cartCount$ | async }}) ``` I also have created a repo with the app and it uses the RxJS functionalities to add reactivity to the app. [Try It App with RxJS.](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-hhwc8c?file=src/app/cart.service.ts) Also, if this gets added, we can also introduce the dev to `async` pipe, `ChangeDetectionStrategy.OnPush` and Immutability
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Docs: Add 'Adding reactivity' section to 'Try It' in the 'Getting Started' guide" (#40275)

Issues.Title: service-worker not initializing when 'enabled' is a variable
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/service-worker ### Is this a regression? No ### Description Setting the enabled property of the ServiceWorkerModule.register function to a boolean variable instead of a const expression (true/false) does not register the service worker even if the variable becomes true. Propably because of AoT compilation(?) ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction this does not work ```ts const serviceWorkerEnabled = !!(config.general.production && (window as any).cordova == null); console.log(`[ServiceWorker] enabled: ${serviceWorkerEnabled}`); // prints true ServiceWorkerModule.register('./ngsw-worker.js', { enabled: serviceWorkerEnabled , registrationStrategy: 'registerImmediately', }), ``` this does work ```ts ServiceWorkerModule.register('./ngsw-worker.js', { enabled: true, registrationStrategy: 'registerImmediately', }), ``` I have tested it with the following override to make sure that the function is not called ```ts const originalFn = navigator.serviceWorker.register; navigator.serviceWorker.register = (a: any, b: any) => { console.log('registration called'); return originalFn(a,b); }; ``` ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**

Issues.Title: docs(router): Clarify how to clear secondary routes
Issues.Body:
The example for clearing secondary outlets currently only works because
the named outlet appears at the root of the application's route config.
If developers follow this example with an outlet that is not at the
root level, they will not be able to close the outlet.
This commit updates the example to provide a more robust way
of clearing the outlet from the activated outlet component
as well as providing a warning about how the commands are applied.

Lastly, there is a small bit of guidance provided for developers who
might want to explore the ability to close an outlet from any location
in the app, without needing to be aware of the activated route.
An example of this can be found here:
https://stackblitz.com/edit/close-outlet-from-anywhere

resolves #13523

Question to reviewers: 
I wonder if I should omit the last bit about closing the outlet using `navigateByUrl` because it goes beyond the common use-cases of just closing the outlet from either the parent that opened it or the activated child itself.
It's quite an advanced topic and complicated to explain but may still be something that devs want to do.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "docs(router): Clarify how to clear secondary routes" (#40272)

Issues.Title: fix(compiler): don't report parse error for interpolation inside string in property binding
Issues.Body:
Currently we check whether a property binding contains an interpolation using a regex so that we can throw an error. The problem is that the regex doesn't account for quotes which means that something like `[prop]="'{{ foo }}'"` will be considered an error, even though it's not actually an interpolation.

These changes build on top of the logic from #39826 to account for interpolation characters inside quotes.

Fixes #39601.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(compiler): don't report parse error for interpolation inside string in property binding" (#40267)

Issues.Title: fix(compiler): incorrectly encapsulating selectors with escape sequences
Issues.Body:
CSS supports escaping in selectors, e.g. writing `.foo:bar` will match an element with the `foo` class and `bar` pseudo-class, but `.foo\:bar` will match the `foo:bar` class. Our shimmed shadow DOM encapsulation always assumes that `:` means a pseudo selector which breaks a selector like `.foo\:bar`.

These changes add some extra logic so that escaped characters in selectors are preserved.

Fixes #31844.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(compiler): incorrectly encapsulating selectors with escape sequences" (#40264)

Issues.Title: fix(compiler): incorrectly inferring content type of SVG-specific title tag
Issues.Body:
The parser has a list of tag definitions that it uses when parsing the template. Each tag has a `contentType` which tells the parser what kind of content the tag should contain. The problem is that the browser has two separate `title` tags (`HTMLTitleElement` and `SVGTitleElement`) and each of them has to have a different `contentType`, otherwise the parser will throw an error further down the pipeline.

These changes update the tag definitions so that each tag name can have multiple content types associated with it and the correct one can be returned based on the element's prefix.

Fixes #31503.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(compiler): incorrectly inferring content type of SVG-specific title tag" (#40259)

Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature Proposal

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> This feature request is for @angular/core


### Description

This proposal adds the first-class support of the [`AbortSignal`](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/AbortSignal) web standard.
AbortSignal is not only for Fetch API but will be used for unregistering DOM event listeners. 

[add signal to addEventListener by benjamingr ¬∑ Pull Request \#919 ¬∑ whatwg/dom](https://github.com/whatwg/dom/pull/919)

AbortSignal will become a new web-standard for various async tasks. If a component exposes its signal on destroyed, developers can use it for interop to other web-compatible (abortable) APIs.

RxJS team is also considering adding support of AbortSignal for automatic unsubscribing subscriptions.

[Discussion: AbortSignal approach ¬∑ Issue \#5863 ¬∑ ReactiveX/rxjs](https://github.com/ReactiveX/rxjs/issues/5863)

### Describe the solution you'd like

This is still a rough idea. I think `ElementRef` can expose its aborting signal.

```ts
@Component()
export class SomeComponent {

  constructor(private elRef: ElementRef) {}

  ngOnInit() {
    const signal: AbortSignal = this.elRef.abortSignal;

    // DOM event
    window.addEventListener('keyup', ..., { signal });

    // Fetch
    fetch(url, {signal}).then(...);

    // RxJS
    someStream$.subscribe(handler, { signal });
  }
}
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Proposal: Component AbortSignal Support" (#40247)

Issues.Title: AngularJS => Angular migration and ng-annotate
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

### Description

Pretty much these other issues explain the motivations for my feature request: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/6873 by @yjaaidi and https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/3722 by @Itrulia

I'm migrating an app from AngularJs to Angular, and even when building for production I'm needing to specify `--optimization=false` because otherwise, the AngularJs parts of my app won't work. The reason is when using Angular CLI there is no way of including `ng-annotate` as part of the pipeline for the AngularJs bits.

What is the 2021 way of using ng-annotate for hybrid applications?

Thanks.

### Describe the solution you'd like
I would like a "plugins" section where I could specify "ng-annotate" and only for files that match a regex (the AngularJs files).

### Describe alternatives you've considered
I've considered:
1. **Ejecting the configuration and not using ng-cli.** I don't like this solution as I want to use Angular CLI and reduce customizations (so upcoming upgrades are smoother).
1. **Running ng-annotate on each of the Angular files by hand, and permanently replacing the original files.** But it's rather involved, I'd need to write a script that:
    - Removes the imports from the top of my files (because ng-annotate doesn't like "imports/exports" in non-module files).
    - Runs ng-annotate in each one, redirecting the output to a file, then swapping the files.
1. **Continuing to use the non-optimized version of my product in production**. My company's product is quite large, and it is taking several seconds to download and bootstrap, so this is exactly what I want to avoid.
1. **Using a custom webpack config prepended to ng-cli's one.** I found it [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/59302237/how-to-use-ng-annotate-with-hybrid-app-based-on-angular-cli).

So far it looks like number 4 is what I'm going to try, otherwise doing number 2. Unless there is already a better solution I have not considered.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "AngularJS => Angular migration and ng-annotate" (#19692)

Issues.Title: "ng build --prod" fails with TypeError when NODE_ENV is set to "development"
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [x] build ### Is this a regression? I am not sure. I have not encountered this error before. ### Description I have added a script in `package.json` to generate dist files for production. ``` { "scripts": { "build:prod": "ng build --prod --output-path dist" } } ``` When I run `npm run build:prod` and the `NODE_ENV` is set to `development` in the terminal, I get the following error, ``` Error: TypeError: Cannot read property 'kind' of undefined at D:\myproject\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:2562:166 at assert (D:\myproject\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:2483:127) at Object.assertNode (D:\myproject\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:2562:17) at visitNode (D:\myproject\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:78336:18) ``` When I set `NODE_ENV` to anything other than `development`, it works fine. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Add the following to the `scripts` section of the `package.json` file, ``` "build:prod": "ng build --prod --output-path dist" ``` Set `NODE_ENV` to `development` and run the script. Run the following lines on powershell (I'm on windows 10). ``` $env:NODE_ENV="development" npm run build:prod ``` ## üî• Exception or Error 

Error: TypeError: Cannot read property 'kind' of undefined
    at D:\myproject\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:2562:166
    at assert (D:\myproject\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:2483:127)
    at Object.assertNode (D:\myproject\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:2562:17)
    at visitNode (D:\myproject\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:78336:18)
    at Object.visitEachChild (D:\myproject\node_modules\typescript\lib\typescript.js:78738:124)

Issues.Title: CSS Module imports stopped working from v10 to v11.
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression? Yes. V10 worked. ### Description Up to and including Angular 10, it was possible to use [CSS Modules](https://github.com/css-modules/css-modules) to import CSS into the script of the component (via the `:export` function on the .scss file and `import styles from "../foo.scss";` within the script of the component). You can see a live example [here](https://scss-import-angular-v10.herokuapp.com/), a minimal reproduction of which is linked below. The variable was imported from the .scss into the .ts and then consequently available within the html too. This has stopped working in v11 with more details below. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Working example https://github.com/chrissyast/scss-import-ng-ten Not working example https://github.com/chrissyast/scss-import-ng-eleven ## üî• Exception or Error `import styles from "../styles.scss"` gives an error ` "export 'default' (imported as 'styles') was not found in '../styles.scss'` `const styles = require("../styles.scss")` works but it is not possible to extract the variable from the created map ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: Allow `+` in lazy-loaded module schematic
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

### Command
- [x] generate

### Description

Some Angular good practices for architecture use a `+` in lazy-loaded modules paths, so it's clearly visible it's lazy-loaded. The official documentation was recommending this practice in previous versions (but maybe not anymore).

Unfortunately, `ng g module features/+hello --route hello --module app` is currently failing, as it also generates a root component, and its selector is guessed from the path. And `+` is not allowed in component selectors.

### Describe the solution you'd like

It would be easy in the schematic to remove the `+` from the selector when generating the root component. **I can take care of the PR.**

### Describe alternatives you've considered

It's not just about a naming convention. One thing very important with lazy-loaded modules is that you must not import things from another module (otherwise lazy-loading is broken).

With a special character like `+` in the path, it's easy to add just one lint rule to check there is no cross-imports.

Otherwise, you have to prohibit each lazy-loaded module path, and add a rule each time you add a new lazy-loaded module.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Allow `+` in lazy-loaded module schematic" (#19666)

Issues.Title: Referencing images is still either broken or very inconsistent (css + html)
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [x] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Unknown ### Description When referencing images, there is wild mix of broken or inconsistent behaviour through `ng serve`, `ng test` and `ng build`. Especially when images are referenced from css files and when the intention is running the deployed app from a subdirectory. It is also trivially to reproduce. I tried to follow up on all of those changes with how [urls are treated](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/4778#issuecomment-280798718) but the varying mix up of broken behaviour is noteworthy. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction * Init project with `ng new image-test --style css --strict` * Select No for routing * Save the following image into the `src/assets` folder: https://angular.io/assets/images/logos/angular/angular.png * Replace `app.component.html` with this: ```html

Sample. TWO images should be displayed

``` * Insert into `app.component.css` the following style: ```css .the-image { width: 200px; height: 200px; background: url('../assets/angular.png') no-repeat; } ``` Depending of the type of path in the css file you get very different results. The scenario above: * `ng serve` -> works * `ng build --base-href '/image-test/'` -> angular.png is now placed in two locations at `dist/image-test` and in `dist/image-test/assets` * `ng test` -> karma dies hard. Starts chrome, chokes and dies. See error section. If one start to mix up paths you get into different hells. I tried absolute paths in css, e.g. `/assets/angular.png`, but beside a configuration that I have to do so that karma does not choke on this, I was unable to figure out, how to run such an app from a subfolder, because during `ng build` all absolute css paths are untouched and 404 on a webserver when serving from `/image-test/` because the paths point to `/assets/angular.png` which is 404, the file is rather located at `/image-test/assets/angular.png` ## üî• Exception or Error * `ng build --base-href '/image-test/'` -> angular.png is now placed in **two** locations at the `top level` and in `assets`. Why do I need doubling the resources? * `ng test` -> karma chokes and dies with this exception: ``` 22 12 2020 10:24:24.449:ERROR [karma-server]: UnhandledRejection: Cannot read property 'range' of undefined 22 12 2020 10:24:24.449:ERROR [karma-server]: TypeError: Cannot read property 'range' of undefined at handleRangeHeaders (d:\image-test\node_modules\webpack-dev-middleware\lib\util.js:131:21) at processRequest (d:\image-test\node_modules\webpack-dev-middleware\lib\middleware.js:98:19) at ready (d:\image-test\node_modules\webpack-dev-middleware\lib\util.js:53:12) at handleRequest (d:\image-test\node_modules\webpack-dev-middleware\lib\util.js:182:5) at d:\image-test\node_modules\webpack-dev-middleware\lib\middleware.js:64:7 at new Promise () at middleware (d:\image-test\node_modules\webpack-dev-middleware\lib\middleware.js:63:12) at d:\image-test\node_modules\@angular-devkit\build-angular\src\webpack\plugins\karma.js:288:13 at call (d:\image-test\node_modules\connect\index.js:239:7) at next (d:\image-test\node_modules\connect\index.js:183:5) at d:\image-test\node_modules\karma\lib\web-server.js:24:9 at call (d:\image-test\node_modules\connect\index.js:239:7) at next (d:\image-test\node_modules\connect\index.js:183:5) at nullProxy (d:\image-test\node_modules\karma\lib\middleware\proxy.js:86:52) at call (d:\image-test\node_modules\connect\index.js:239:7) at next (d:\image-test\node_modules\connect\index.js:183:5)``` ``` When I comment out only the css part and add this snippet to `karma.conf.js` ```js proxies: { '/assets/': '/base/src/assets/', }, files: [ { pattern: './src/assets/**', watched: false, included: false, nocache: false, served: true } ], ``` I could run ng test, with broken styles but at least with some images (the image referenced from html will work). Using relative paths I was unable to make `ng test` run, but maybe I am just lacking some more configuration ## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 11.0.5
Node: 14.15.2
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 11.0.5
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1100.5
@angular-devkit/build-angular   0.1100.5
@angular-devkit/core            11.0.5
@angular-devkit/schematics      11.0.5
@schematics/angular             11.0.5
@schematics/update              0.1100.5
rxjs                            6.6.3
typescript                      4.0.5
**Anything else relevant?** Developing on windows 10 x64 (1903) Maybe relevant: The css url `background: url('../assets/angular.png')` is compacted to `angular.png` during `ng serve`. Regardless how deep I nest the png file into `assets`, even when I move the file deeper and reference it via `background: url('../assets/many/levels/deep/angular.png')`, `ng serve` will still fetch `/angular.png` which is probably why karma cannot handle it properly as well.

Issues.Title: bug(Angular Material 11 Samples): Sample projects don't work locally
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction
Steps to reproduce:
1. Got to sample input component page https://material.angular.io/components/input/overview
2. Click on the "Edit basic inputs example in StackBlitz"
3. Sample app works fine
4. Download code locally: (Fork the project,  Connect repository, clone the repo locally)
5. In the local project folder run "npm install"
6. run "npm run start"
7. in browser go to http://localhost:4200/
8. App does not render (shows "loading Current build: 11.0.3")

Same behavior with other Angular Material 11 sample projects
Same steps with Angular Material 10 samples work fine
Noe: If I change the index.html content to place the component directive inside the "body" element directly, it renders, but the formatting is not applied. 
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

At step 8 I expect to see the same behavior as I see in Stackblitz sample or with Angular Material 10 local app
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11194908/103229835-e45c9600-4901-11eb-8b19-356349c06380.png)

See step 8

#### Environment

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue:

Steps to reproduce:
1. Click on the calendar icon and select 12/9/2020 (9th December 2020) 
2. In the datepicker textbox remove the month part of the date , after editing the value should be /9/2020
3. Press tab or click outside of the textbox. 
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

The value should stay as it is or it must say invalid date.


#### Actual Behavior

The date automatically changes to 9/20/2020


#### Environment

- Angular:
- CDK/Material: Material, DatePicker
- Browser(s):  Chrome, Firefox
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MomentDateAdapter: When Focous is out after deleting the month it autocompletes to random date." (#21459)

Issues.Title: fix(material/menu): adjust overlay size when amount of items changes
Issues.Body:
Currently we lock the menu into a position after it is opened so that it doesn't jump around when the user scrolls, but this means that if the amount of items changes, it might not be the optimal position anymore.

These changes add some code to re-calculate the position if the amount of items changes.

Fixes #21456.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/menu): adjust overlay size when amount of items changes" (#21457)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-menu/cdk-overlay): mat-menu items are clipped when content height grows after menu is opened.
Issues.Body: #### Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-sfz2cr Steps to reproduce: 1. scroll the inner pink box to make the menu open downwards, but the opened menu just touches the bottom, like this: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11501545/103199861-babf5280-48a0-11eb-9745-d63e151affb6.png) 2. The bug also happens on the opposite direction, when opening the menu upwards and the menu top touches the viewport top, like this: 3. after 1 second, 20 new items will be added to the menu to make the menu longer. 4. notice the menu is clipped and not all items are visible. This only happens when the menu trigger is in a scrollable area. #### Expected Behavior The menu should be able to scroll and see all items. #### Actual Behavior the menu is clipped #### Environment - Angular: 11.0.6 - CDK/Material: 11.0.3 - Browser(s): Version 87.0.4280.88 (Official Build) (x86_64) - Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS 10.15.7
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-menu/cdk-overlay): mat-menu items are clipped when content height grows after menu is opened." (#21456)

Issues.Title: CSS Transition not working when using from style.scss
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: 
- Components: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-transistion-issue?file=package.json

Steps to reproduce:
1.  Create two class with different name with same transition property
2.  Add one in style.scss and other one in **your-component**.scss
3. Transition property work as expected when used from your component, but not working from **style.scss**

![transition-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4208015/103172555-55586b00-487a-11eb-931c-3959ac1b2df8.gif)

 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
Should have similar behavior. 

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
Transition not working **whereas media queries are working** when using from style.scss.
Either nothing works or all works.

#### Environment
```
 "@angular/animations": "^10.0.9",
    "@angular/cdk": "11.0.3",
    "@angular/common": "^10.0.9",
    "@angular/compiler": "^10.0.9",
    "@angular/core": "^10.0.9",
    "@angular/forms": "^10.0.9",
    "@angular/material": "^11.0.3",
    "@angular/platform-browser": "^10.0.9",
    "@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "^10.0.9",
    "@angular/router": "^10.0.9",
    "rxjs": "^6.6.2",
    "tslib": "^2.0.1",
    "zone.js": "^0.10.3"
```
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System - Windows,  Generic

Issues.Title: build: bump @bazel/rollup from 2.3.1 to 3.0.0
Issues.Body:
Bumps [@bazel/rollup](https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/tree/HEAD/packages/rollup) from 2.3.1 to 3.0.0.
Release notes

Sourced from @bazel/rollup's releases.

3.0.0

Following our usual 6-month cadence for major releases, here is 3.0.0 just in time for your winter vacation! As usual, we've done our best to make breaking changes that improve the long-term health of the project and which are easy to adopt. Give us feedback in the #javascript channel on slack.bazel.build

üëèüèª Thanks to our awesome contributors for this release! üëèüèª

@mistic, @lukasholzer, @duarten, @jbedard, @mrmeku , @opelhoward , @Schibum , @mattinsler , @JiaLiPassion , @fredrikredflag , @KrauseStefan , @comius , @lovepocky , @tylerhou and @OlaviSau

To upgrade:

http_archive(
    name = "build_bazel_rules_nodejs",
    sha256 = "6142e9586162b179fdd570a55e50d1332e7d9c030efd853453438d607569721d",
    urls = ["https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/releases/download/3.0.0/rules_nodejs-3.0.0.tar.gz"],
)

and upgrade your @bazel-scoped npm packages (you'll get an error when installing 2.x version packages with rules_nodejs 3.x)

Finally, read the üìö Migration instructions from 2.x for breaking changes: https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/wiki#migrating-to-30

BREAKING CHANGES

Stricter installs

For both yarn_install and npm_install we now fail if the lockfile is out-of-date, rather than update it. This assumes you'll use the tooling to manually update the lockfile as needed.

yarn_install now passes --frozen_lockfile by default, but you can use yarn_install(frozen_lockfile = False) to go back to the old behavior.

npm_install now has an attribute npm_command that defaults to ci but you can set it to install to go back to the old behavior.

We also flipped the default for strict_visibility on these two rules. This prevents you adding a Bazel dependency on a library that isn't listed as a dependency in package.json. You can set it back to False if you need the old behavior.

--bazel_patch_module_resolver defaults to false

By default, we no longer patch the require() function, instead you should rely on the linker to make node modules resolvable at the standard location if this breaks you, the quickest fix is to flip the flag back on a nodejs_binary/nodejs_test/npm_package_bin with templated_args = ["--bazel_patch_module_resolver"], see bazelbuild/rules_nodejs#2344 as an example. Another fix is to explicitly use our runfiles helper library, see bazelbuild/rules_nodejs#2341 as an example.

karma and ts_devserver rules moved to new package @bazel/concatjs

packages/karma:package.bzl is gone, in your WORKSPACE replace

load("//packages/karma:package.bzl", "npm_bazel_karma_dependencies")

</tr></table>

... (truncated)

Changelog

Sourced from @bazel/rollup's changelog.

3.0.0 (2020-12-22)

Bug Fixes

  • builtin: only pass kwargs to the test, not the .update binary (#2361) (afa095b)

Code Refactoring

  • builtin: remove node_modules attribute from nodejs_binary, nodejs_test & ts_library (c2927af)

BREAKING CHANGES

  • builtin: We removed the node_modules attribute from nodejs_binary, nodejs_test, jasmine_node_test & ts_library.

If you are using the node_modules attribute, you can simply add the target specified there to the data or deps attribute of the rule instead.

For example,

nodejs_test(
    name = "test",
    data = [
        "test.js",
        "@npm//:node_modules",
    ],
    entry_point = "test.js",
)

or

ts_library(
    name = "lib",
    srcs = glob(["*.ts"]),
    tsconfig = ":tsconfig.json",
    deps = ["@npm//:node_modules"],
)

We also dropped support for filegroup based node_modules target and removed node_modules_filegroup from index.bzl.

If you are using this feature for user-managed deps, you must now a js_library target with external_npm_package set to True instead.

For example,

... (truncated)

Commits
  • c2927af refactor(builtin): remove node_modules attribute from nodejs_binary, nodejs_t...
  • ea34460 chore: cleanup flag settings which are now redundant with the default
  • 68b18d8 chore: remove old stamping

Issues.Title: build: update to gulp 4
Issues.Body:
We still depend on Gulp for a couple of CI tasks, but we've been stuck on version 3.8 for a while which doesn't support Node 12 (without workarounds) and might break in other ways in the future.

These changes update us to version 4.0.2, account for the breaking changes and remove some dependencies that have been replaced by functions in Gulp.

Issues.Title: fix(dialog) make align attribute into an input of dialog actions directive instead of css
Issues.Body:
Fixes multiple issues, such as self-documentation of the align attribute, type checking, better bindings, and IDE support. Because align is not standard for HTMLDivElement, it doesn't make much sense to assume end users to know they can use the align attribute.

Fixes #18479
